title: Riot should "employ" game mods to police bad behaviour
body:
Get a team of say 50 (more if possible) regular players from a variety of divisions. Mods are rewarded with RP so it technically cost the company nothing. Basically these mods can provide instant feedback to Riot with harsher penalties. Basically, you see these players in the game, you know not to mess around. Riot has said themselves that they don't want to be the police and want to leave it more up to the community to set "what is acceptable". This would be a great way of more or less having a RealTime Tribunal, I feel this would be hugely popular

Obviously these mods would be trusted players from within the community. I don't pass that test, but I'm sure there are plenty that would

replies.body:
Man id mod for free.

I keep mentioning those 10-15 tos breakers i know that slip under the system no matter how many times i report them.

Thats half a division group cleared of trolls right there.

I just thought RP might be an incentive to get people to do it. And I can see the cons of the system, providing certain players with powers that could be abused. But that's why you keep the team at a reasonable volume and punish those who abuse the power.

But I totally agree with you, I've got to the point now where I have a list of tos breakers. If I see someone that looks familiar, look them up in the list. If they're in the list it's a dodge

Yeah i was keeping a list but i very quickly realized that i was losing more lp from dodging than i was gaining from not playing with players on the list.

Thats when i realized just how frequent these trolls really are, they arent like one off cases where they had a bad day or something.

These people specifically log into league of legends to ruin peoples days, and yet they are still not banned.

This is why i have no confidence in riots ability to actually maintain a community, just as people have no confidence in their ability to maintain game balance.

To be honest i blame upper management for prioritizing money making methods over the health of their game.

Well, the Tribunal Voting system *is* coming back. It will be a priority after they are done with the new Champ Select (if it's not already) according to Lyte. https://ask.fm/RiotLyte/answers/134415323842

Watching a match to moderate would take an insane amount of manpower, though. There are simply too many games going on at once to individually do this. That is why the system flags players for an audit after they are reported too often, rather than auditing them every time (either by the automated system or manually).

They said that what 4 years ago? 5 years now?

i have zero confidence in riots ability to provide a functioning report system.

well the community is saying no more bots
and they didn't do shit

And lets say these mods don't like you. Subjective judgement may come into play.
I'd prefer it if the 50 human mods were a team that worked on reports sent in by players, rather than have it automated. It would have these mods immensely if Riot had their own replay system for games.

50 people monitoring a single game each, the only game that they themselves must play in and moderate at the same time without feeding. is that the type of moderating you mean? they have to be in game? thats too little, nobody would notice them, i play at midnight, is there gonna be 1 thats monitoring unranked/low MMR arams and/or norms at 3am? 500 perfect mods would be ideal, but in reality, any case of power abuse will be really detrimental to riot, especially since they seem to interact with the community a lot, and ignoring our reports of mod abuse or dealing with each and every one of them in an assertive and friendly manner will take too much effort
